Award.AwardTitle: CRII: RI: Energy Effective and Versatile Bipedal Robots Using Event-Based Switching Between Parameterized Steady-State Controllers

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Bipedal robots, unlike humans, are either energy-effective or versatile but not both at the same time. For example, the Honda ASIMO can walk over stairs and navigate around obstacles but needs to be recharged about every hour or so. On the other hand, robots inspired by passive dynamics use trivial amounts of energy to move but are limited to a single speed and step length. This project develops a theory that fills this knowledge gap by enabling bipedal robots to make informed decisions about what strategy to follow given a particular circumstance. For example, on rough terrains, a robot may have to decide to expend more energy in order to maximize stability while, in cases where the terrain is flat and regular, the same robot can decide to use its most energy-efficient gait while paying little heed to stability.

There is a need to develop a theory that would simultaneously enable improved performance metrics for the energy-efficiency and versatility of bipedal robots. The instability of bipedal robots, due to their inverted pendulum like nature, makes this challenge even greater; hence, metrics for balance and stability also need to be met simultaneously. The gap in knowledge is that, it is unclear how to enable bipedal robots to satisfy all these performance metrics, some of which can actually be conflicting (e.g., energy-efficiency trade-offs with stability).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Bipedal robots, unlike humans, are energy-effective or versatile, but not both at the same time. Energy efficiency enables long-term use between recharges, while versatility enables navigation on complex terrains, both of which are essential for such robots to find use in mainstream applications. However, bipedal robots because of their intrinsically unstable dynamics (i.e., inverted pendulum-like nature) also need to be stabilized. The project aimed to enable energy effective, versatile legged systems while simultaneously considering balance and stability.

 

To address this technical gap, we proceeded as follows. First, we created a control framework that enables the generation of energy-efficient and stability controllers for periodic gaits, say walking at 1m/s. Second, we created representations to encode these controllers for each periodic gait. Third, to enable versatile movement, we composed these controllers to switch between periodic gaits. Thus, given a novel scenario, the biped can make an informed decision on what movement pattern to follow and how to execute that particular movement without failling down. 

 

The grant also explored other supporting ideas that include finding controls for balance and stability (e.g., ankle push-off vs. foot placement), investigating the synergy between the controls, and the role of leg design and geometry on energy efficiency and stability. In addition, an undergraduate team built a quadruped and a master's student built a rimless wheeled legged robot.


The results from the grant were communicated through referred journal and conference publications, a review paper, poster sessions, and at an informal conference (i.e., dynamic walking), all student's reports, papers, code, design files are posted on the PI's website. The PI mentored 3 undergraduate senior design teams, 12 students. In addition, about 10 undergraduate students took part in independent projects, some over multiple semesters, some of whom were supported through stipends and engineering fellowship. A total of 4 Master's students received partial support, and 2 Ph.D. students received full tuition and salary support. The PI developed a service-learning component to the robotics course where students in the robotics class mentored 220 elementary- and middle-school students in south San Antonio, Texas, in mainly economically disadvantaged neighborhoods. The results from the service-learning were disseminated through an engineering education conference paper. The control framework developed here has broad applications in other legged systems such as jumping, running, climbing, and juggling robots and to control artificial devices such as exoskeletons and prosthesis.
